div1.head: Newspaper clipping, La Lucha, July 13, 1908
div1.p:
One of the most gratifying results
o the present occupation of Cuba
by the American forces, is the re-es-
tablishment of a high order of san-
itation. Although a stupendous un-
dertaking, the army medical officers,
during the first intervention brought
order out o chaos and a good hy-
gienic condition out of what was a
putrid city. While doing this in
Havana, none of the other import-
ant places of the island were neg-
lected. When the republic of Cuba
was established one of its primal
obligations was to maintain the
hygienic conditions in which the
Americans left the country. This
important duty was overlooked and
the conditions soon fell into a very
bad state.

Upon the return of the American
army to Cuba in 1906 they found
that Cuba had only escaped a
scourge of sickness because of the
natural healthfulness of the coun-
try and not because the sanitation
had been kept up. It was discov-
ered that the work had to be begun
from the ground up again and Major
Kean was immediately put on the
job as a likely man to reconstruct
that department. What he has had
to do and to contend with has been a
sore trial for that gentleman. It is
said the stegomyia has not given
him the greatest trouble, but the
multitude of political pests which
have besieged him for places has
made life a burden and has hindered
his work tremendously. It is un-
derstood that he has not always had
his way in things, but has had men
thrust upon him, because some pol-
itician recommended him regardless
of the man's fitness for the work he
had to undertake. Under the condi-
tions it is thought Major Kean and
his immediate assistants deserve high
encomiums for the splendid work
they had done in re-establishing the
health o the island.
